problem:

choices:

The question asks for an elastic impression material that sets by a chemical reaction and is catalyzed by chloroplatinic acid. Polyvinyl siloxane fits this description.

problem:
Under MCH programme, iron and folic acid tablets to be given daily to mother has
Choices:
  A: 100 mg iron + 500 mcg folic acid
  B: 60 mg iron + 500 mcg folic acid
  C: 60 mg iron + 100 mcg folic acid
  D: 100 mg iron + 100 mcg folic acid
choices:
Choices:
  A: 100 mg iron + 500 mcg folic acid
  B: 60 mg iron + 500 mcg folic acid
  C: 60 mg iron + 100 mcg folic acid
  D: 100 mg iron + 100 mcg folic acid
response:
Thought: 
Under the Maternal and Child Health (MCH) programme, the recommended daily dosage of iron and folic acid for pregnant women is 100 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg (0.5 mg) of folic acid.
Action: Answer("A")
solution:
An adult tablet of IFA contains: 100 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic acid (to be given for 100 days minimum in pregnancy).
A pediatric tablet of IFA contains: 20 mg elemental Iron and 100 mcg Folic acid (to be given for 100 days minimum every year till 5 years age of child).

problem:
Type 2 pattern of etched enamel is also known as:
Choices:
  A: Honeycomb pattern
  B: Soap bubble pattern
  C: Cobble stone pattern
  D: Pyramid pattern
choices:
Choices:
  A: Honeycomb pattern
  B: Soap bubble pattern
  C: Cobble stone pattern
  D: Pyramid pattern
response:
Thought: 
The Type 2 pattern of etched enamel is referred to as the cobblestone pattern in dental medicine. 
Action: Answer("C")
solution:
According to Silverstone et al and Galil Wright 
Type I

Selective removal of enamel prism cores.
Peripheries intact (honeycomb appearance).

Type II 

 Reverse process.
 Peripheries removed.
 Cores intact (cobble stone appearance  with prism edges lost).

Type III is the mixture of pattern I and II.
Type IV – Pitted enamel with map like appearance.
Type V – flat smooth surfaces

problem:
In anaerobic glycolysis, end product is -
Choices:
  A: 2 ATP + 2 NAD
  B: 2 ATP
  C: 2 ATP + 2 NADH
  D: 4 ATP + 2 FADH2
choices:
Choices:
  A: 2 ATP + 2 NAD
  B: 2 ATP
  C: 2 ATP + 2 NADH
  D: 4 ATP + 2 FADH2
response:
Thought: 
Anaerobic glycolysis is a metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose in the absence of oxygen, producing ATP and NADH. However, the NADH produced in glycolysis is used to reduce pyruvate to lactate, regenerating the NAD+ needed for glycolysis to continue. Therefore, the net end products are 2 ATP and 2 NAD+.
Action: Answer("A")
solution: Anaerobic Glycolysis ETC is not working hence NADH cannot enter ETC to form ATP. NADH is used to regenerate NAD by LDH Lactate is the end of anaerobic glycolysis. Net gain of ATP: 4 ATP produced (substrate level phosphorylation) - 2 ATP used (one by Hexokinase , other used by PFK-1) =2 ATP(net gain). 2 NAD are obtained after lactate formation but 2 NAD are used also in glyceraldehyde dehydrogenase step. So Net Gain of NAD = 0 Net gain at the end is 2ATP But here, they are asking about end product. At the end of anaerobic glycolysis, 2 ATP and 2 NAD are obtained. So when asked about end product then you have to mark 2ATP + 2NAD. But if asked about net gain then mark only 2 ATP.

problem:
In obstruction of second pa of axillary aery, the anastomosis between the following aery will maintain the blood supply of upper limb
Choices:
  A: Deep branch of transverse cervical aery & subscapular aery
  B: Anterior & posterior circumflex humeral
  C: Posterior circumflex humeral & circumflex scapular aery
  D: Suprascapular & anterior circumflex humeral aery
choices:
Choices:
  A: Deep branch of transverse cervical aery & subscapular aery
  B: Anterior & posterior circumflex humeral
  C: Posterior circumflex humeral & circumflex scapular aery
  D: Suprascapular & anterior circumflex humeral aery
response:
Thought: 
The deep branch of the transverse cervical artery and the subscapular artery form an anastomotic network that can provide collateral circulation to the upper limb in case of obstruction in the second part of the axillary artery.
Action: Answer("A")
solution: When the axillary aery is blocked, collateral circulation is established through the anastomosis around scapula which links the first pa of the subclan aery with the third pa of axillary aery(apa from the communications with the posterior intercostal aeries). The transverse cervical aery is a branch of the subclan aery and the subscapular aery is a branch of the second pa of the axillary aery. BD Chaurasia 7th edition Page no: 55

problem:
Senescent RBC's are mainly attacked in-
Choices:
  A: Vivax malaria
  B: Ovale malaria
  C: Falciparum malaria
  D: Quartan malaria
choices:
Choices:
  A: Vivax malaria
  B: Ovale malaria
  C: Falciparum malaria
  D: Quartan malaria
response:
Thought: 
Plasmodium malariae, the parasite that causes Quartan malaria, is known to infect older, senescent red blood cells.
Action: Answer("D")
solution:
P. malariae which attacks mainly senescent (old) RBC’s: Agent of Quartan malaria
P. ovale and P. vivax: attack younger RBCs and reticulocytes: Agent of benign tertian malaria
P. falciparum: attacks RBC of all ages: Agent of malignant tertian malaria.

problem:
Who has given root canal isthmus classification?
Choices:
  A: Kim
  B: Schielder
  C: Krasner and Rankow
  D: Vertucci
choices:
Choices:
  A: Kim
  B: Schielder
  C: Krasner and Rankow
  D: Vertucci
response:
Thought: 
The root canal isthmus classification was given by Krasner and Rankow.
Action: Answer("C")
solution:
Kim et al Classification
Root apex cross-section
Narrow ribbon-shaped connection that contains pulp or pulpally derived tissue - ISTHMUS
According to Kim et al classification; there are 5 types:

Type I : Incomplete isthmus between 2 canals.
Type II : Well defined, complete isthmus between 2 canals.
Type III : Very short, but complete isthmus between 2 canals.
Type IV : 3 or more canals with the complete or incomplete isthmus.
Type V : 3 or more canals without any visible connection.

problem:
Site of transplantation in Islet cell transplant for Diabetes mellitus is
Choices:
  A: Skin
  B: Injected into the poal vein
  C: Liver

choices:
Choices:
  A: Skin
  B: Injected into the poal vein
  C: Liver
  D: Pelvis
response:
Thought: 
Islet cell transplantation for Diabetes mellitus involves transplanting islet cells into the liver of the patient. However, the method of transplantation is through injection into the portal vein, which carries blood to the liver.

solution: The islets are then purified from the dispersed tissue by density-gradient centrifugation and can be delivered into the recepient liver (the preferred site for transplantation) by injection into the poal vein Ref: Bailey and love 27th edition Pgno :1552

problem:
60-year-old male complaints of right-sided nasal obstruction and nasal discharge, which sometimes is blood tinged. Biopsy finding is also shown below. What is your diagnosis?
Choices:
  A: Rhinoscleroma
  B: Wegener's granulomatosis
  C: Stewa's granuloma
  D: Rhinosporidiosis
choices:
Choices:
  A: Rhinoscleroma
  B: Wegener's granulomatosis
  C: Stewa's granuloma
  D: Rhinosporidiosis
response:
Thought: 
The question does not provide the biopsy findings, which would be crucial in making a definitive diagnosis. However, based on the symptoms of right-sided nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and blood-tinged discharge, the most likely diagnosis would be Wegener's granulomatosis. This condition is a type of vasculitis that often affects the upper respiratory tract, causing symptoms such as those described in the question. 
Action: Answer("B")
solution: RhinosporidiosisIt is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and affects both man and animals.The disease mostly affects nose and nasopharynxThe disease is acquired through the contaminated water of ponds also frequented by animals. In the nose, the disease presents as a leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall. The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch. Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia of fungus. In early stages, the patient may complain of nasal discharge which is often blood tinged and nasal stuffiness. Sometimes, frank epistaxis is the only presenting complaint.Diagnosis: This is made by biopsy. It shows several sporangia, oval or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall. It has not been possible to culture the organism or transfers the disease to experimental animals.Treatment:Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Not many drugs are effective against the disease. Dapsone has been tried with some success.Ref: Dhingra; 6th ed; Pg: 159

problem:
In Cicatricial pemphigoid, which antigen is bound by IgG on the epidermal side of the salt split skin technique?
Choices:
  A: XVII collagen
  B: Epiligrin
  C: Laminin 5
  D: BP antigen 1 & 2
choices:
Choices:
  A: XVII collagen
  B: Epiligrin
  C: Laminin 5
  D: BP antigen 1 & 2
response:
Thought: 
Cicatricial pemphigoid, also known as mucous membrane pemphigoid, is an autoimmune blistering disease. In this condition, the body's immune system produces antibodies against certain proteins in the skin and mucous membranes. The antigen that is bound by IgG in Cicatricial pemphigoid is BP antigen 1 & 2.
Action: Answer("D")
solution: Majority cases of mucous membrane pemphigoid or cicatricial pemphigoid demonstrate IgG directed against antigens on the epidermal side of the salt-split skin, which have been identified as BP 180 or XVII collagen. The antigen present on the dermal side is epiligrin (laminin 5).

problem:
Primordial prevention is the -
Choices:
  A: Prevention of diseases among the hill-dwelling and tribal people
  B: Prolongation of human life span to the maximum extent
  C: Promotion of health, well being and efficiency
  D: Prevention of diseases through modification of their risk factors
choices:
Choices:
  A: Prevention of diseases among the hill-dwelling and tribal people
  B: Prolongation of human life span to the maximum extent
  C: Promotion of health, well being and efficiency
  D: Prevention of diseases through modification of their risk factors
response:
Thought: 
Primordial prevention refers to actions focusing on avoiding the emergence and establishment of the social, economic, and environmental patterns of living that are known to increase the risk of disease. These are often conditions that are not health promoting. In other words, it is the prevention of diseases through the modification of their risk factors.
Action: Answer("D")
solution: Ans. is 'd' i.e., Prevention of diseases through modification of their risk factors It is the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared

problem:
25 year old primigravida is diagnosed with preeclampsia at 38 weeks gestation. MgSO4 infusion is started for seizure prophylaxis and planned to induce labor. Her cervix is 3cm dilated, slightly soft and located anteriorly. Fetal head is at -1 station, and length of cervix is < 0.5cm. What is her Bishop score
Choices:
  A: 7
  B: 8
  C: 9
  D: 10
choices:
Choices:
  A: 7
  B: 8
  C: 9
  D: 10
response:
Thought: 
The Bishop score is calculated based on five parameters: dilation, effacement, station, cervical consistency, and cervical position. Each parameter is given a score from 0 to 3 (or 0 to 2 for station), and the scores are added together. 
In this case:
- Dilation: 3 cm (score of 2)
- Effacement: <0.5 cm (score of 3)
- Station: -1 (score of 1)
- Cervical consistency: slightly soft (score of 2)
- Cervical position: anterior (score of 2)
Adding these scores together gives a total Bishop score of 10.
Action: Answer("D")
solution:

problem:
In blood buffers Bicarbonates buffers is ideal why?
Choices:
  A: Pka is equal to Ph
  B: High concentration
  C: Weak acid and weak base combination
  D: easy to measure
choices:
Choices:
  A: Pka is equal to Ph
  B: High concentration
  C: Weak acid and weak base combination
  D: easy to measure
response:
Thought: 
Bicarbonate buffers are ideal in blood because they are present in high concentrations. This allows them to effectively neutralize both acids and bases and maintain the blood pH within the narrow range necessary for proper physiological function.
Action: Answer("B")
solution: (High concentration): (711-/2- Shinde 8th edition)Bicarbonate Buffer system* Consists of weak acid "Carbonic acid" (H2CO3) and strong base (HCO3), NaHCO3 (Sodium bicarbonate)* Normal ratio in blood =NaHCO3H2CO3=201* They are the chief buffers of blood and constitute the so called Alkali reserve* Neutralisation of strong and non volatile acids entering the ECF is achieved by the bicarbonate buffers* Bicarbonate buffer system is directly linked up with respiration* Bicarbonate buffers system serve as an index to understand the disturbance in the acid base balance of the body (476- U. Satyanarayan 4th)Advantages of bicarbonate buffer system* It is present in very high concentration than other buffer system (26 to 28 millimole per littre )* Produces H2CO3 which is weak acid and volatile and CO2 is exhaled out* Hence it is a very good physiological buffer and acts as a front line defense.Disadvantages - As a chemical buffer, it is rather weak, pKa is further away from the physiological pH

problem:
Hepatitis A virus shedding in faeces is
Choices:
  A: One week before the symptoms appear
  B: Two weeks after the symptoms appear
  C: One week before the symptoms and one week thereafter
  D: Two weeks before the symptoms and two week thereafter
choices:
Choices:
  A: One week before the symptoms appear
  B: Two weeks after the symptoms appear
  C: One week before the symptoms and one week thereafter
  D: Two weeks before the symptoms and two week thereafter
response:
Thought: 
Hepatitis A virus is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route. The virus is shed in the feces of infected individuals. This shedding begins approximately two weeks before symptoms appear and continues for about two weeks after the onset of symptoms.
Action: Answer("D")

problem:
Major complication of cyst-gastrostomy for pseudo pancreatic cyst is?
Choices:
  A: Infection
  B: Obstruction
  C: Fistula
  D: Hemorrhage
choices:
Choices:
  A: Infection
  B: Obstruction
  C: Fistula
  D: Hemorrhage
response:
Thought: 
Cyst-gastrostomy is a surgical procedure used to treat pancreatic pseudocysts. The major complications of this procedure can include infection, obstruction, fistula formation, and hemorrhage. However, the major complication, which is the most severe and potentially life-threatening, is hemorrhage.
Action: Answer("D")
solution: Ans. (d) HemorrhageRef : CSDTUthed/638* Serious post-op hemorrhage from cyst occurs from cystogastrostomy.* Most common cause of pseudopancreatic cyst is pancreatitis.* It may resolve spontaneously, so it is followed with serial ultrasonic studies.Indications of Surgical Intervention* Age of cyst more than 6 weeks without resolution* Size of cyst greater than 6 cm* Evidence of secondary infection* Development of any other complicationsSurgical Methods* Internal drainage - most preferred surgical management* There are three options:# Cysto-Jejunostomy# Cysto-gastrostomy# Cysto-Duodenostomy* Excision of pseudocyst* External drainage

problem:
A patient underwent lateral skull base surgery few months back and has presented with complaints of recurrent aspirations. There is no change in voice of the patient. Which of the following nerve is most likely injured during surgery?
Choices:
  A: Vagus nerve
  B: Glossopharyngeal nerve
  C: SLN nerve
  D: RLN nerve
choices:
Choices:
  A: Vagus nerve
  B: Glossopharyngeal nerve
  C: SLN nerve
  D: RLN nerve
response: Action: Answer("C")
solution: U/L SLN palsy - MC due to neck surgery . Symptoms - Loss of pitch and aspiration Rx - Conservative U/L RLN palsy - MC is left RLN (because of longer course ) But in neck surgery most common injured is Right RLN because it has superficial course. Symptoms - Hoarseness (paramedian position of vocal cord) Rx - Conservative U/L CN X palsy - MC cause is surgery Symptoms - Hoarseness (due to cadaveric position of vocal cord) and aspiration Rx - Type 1 tyroplasty =In question mention that there is no change in voice but there is aspiration . it is a case of SLN palsy.

problem:
What is the average gain in lenght in 4 years?
Choices:
  A: 25 cm
  B: 50 cm
  C: 75 cm
  D: 100 cm
choices:
Choices:
  A: 25 cm
  B: 50 cm
  C: 75 cm
  D: 100 cm
response:
Thought: 
The average child grows about 5-6 cm per year during the preschool years (ages 3-5). Therefore, over a period of 4 years, the average length gain would be around 20-24 cm per year. Multiplying this by 4 years, we get a range of 80-96 cm. The closest answer to this range is 100 cm.
Action: Answer("D")
solution: Expected height = Age (yr) × 6 + 77

problem:
In Spondylolisthesis, which of the following is NOT useful investigation?
Choices:
  A: Anteroposterior X-ray
  B: Lateral view X-ray
  C: CT
  D: MRI
choices:
Choices:
  A: Anteroposterior X-ray
  B: Lateral view X-ray
  C: CT
  D: MRI
response:
Thought: 
In Spondylolisthesis, all the investigations listed are useful. Anteroposterior X-ray and Lateral view X-ray can show if any vertebrae have slipped forward. CT can provide a more detailed look at the spine and can show if there are any fractures or other problems. MRI can provide detailed images of the soft tissues and nerves around the spine. Therefore, none of the options listed are NOT useful investigations in Spondylolisthesis. 
Action: This question is flawed as all the options are useful investigations in Spondylolisthesis. There is no correct answer.
solution: (a)-AP view will show changes only in last stages-inverted Napoleon hat sign all other are more important for diagnosis and management. CT and MRI are required in all cases.

problem:
At 34 weeks multigravida with previous 2 normal delivery has an unstable lie with the present pregnancy. It can be due to:
Choices:
  A: Oligohydramnios
  B: Placenta pre
  C: Pelvic tumor
  D: Uterine anomalies
choices:
Choices:
  A: Oligohydramnios
  B: Placenta pre
  C: Pelvic tumor
  D: Uterine anomalies
response:
Thought: 
An unstable lie in pregnancy refers to a situation where the baby's position changes frequently. This can be due to several reasons, including placenta previa, which is a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the mother's cervix. This can cause the baby to change positions frequently, resulting in an unstable lie. 
Action: Answer("B")
solution: Placenta pre can be associated with several other conditions, including malpresentation, unstable lie, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and intrauterine growth restriction. There may also be an increased risk of congenital anomalies; however, there is no association with any specific anomaly. Ref: Wagner S.A. (2013). Chapter 18. Third-Trimester Vaginal Bleeding. In A.H. DeCherney, L. Nathan, N. Laufer, A.S. Roman (Eds), CURRENT Diagnosis & Treatment: Obstetrics & Gynecology, 11e.
